content.text: **Fundamental** SI Units:
**Length**: Metre (m)
**Mass**: Kilogram (kg)
**Time**: Second (s)
**Measurement** **accuracy** is very important in science, as small errors can lead to big changes in results.
Common **Mistakes** **to** **Avoid**:
**Alignment**: Always place the object correctly at the "0" mark on the scale.
**Position**: Keep the object parallel to the scale to prevent errors.
**Eye** **Positioning**: Look straight down at the measurement point to avoid parallax error
**Parallax** **error** happens when an object appears to be in a different position when viewed from different angles.
For accurate measurements, your **eye** should be positioned **directly** **above** the measurement point.
Viewing from other angles (like **left** or **right**) can cause **incorrect** **readings** due to parallax.
To avoid parallax error, always make sure your **eye** **is** **aligned** with the measurement point.
**Beam** **Balance**: Measures mass by comparing an object's mass to a standard mass.
**Electronic** **Balance**: Offers accurate mass measurements, commonly used for chemicals, food, groceries, and jewelry.
**Clock**: Tracks time and is used to note the passage of time in daily activities.
**Stopwatch**: Measures time intervals precisely, ideal for races or events.
**Meter** **Scale**: Measures length in metres and centimetres; useful for accurately measuring smaller objects.
**Length** is the **distance** between two points.
**Examples:**
The edges of a book
Distance between corners of a football ground
Distance from home to school.
The standard unit of length is the **metre** (**m**).
**Smaller** **lengths** are measured in **millimetres** (**mm**) and **centimetres** (**cm**).
**Larger** **distances**, like those between cities, are measured in **kilometres** (**km**).
**Mass** is the amount of **matter** in an object.
**Mass** is different from **weight**. Weight is the **gravitational** **pull** on an object, while mass stays the same.
For example, an object will **weigh less on the Moon** (about six times less), but its **mass remains unchanged**.
The SI unit of **mass** is the **kilogram** (**kg)**.
**Smaller** **units** of mass:
**Milligram** (mg): 1000 mg = 1 g.
**Larger** **units** of mass:
**Tonne** (metric tonne): 1000 kg = 1 tonne.
A **beam balance** measures mass by comparing an objectâ€™s mass to a **known** **mass** (standard mass).
With a beam balance, you can:
Find out which object is **heavier**.
**Estimate the weight** of lighter objects, like **leaves** or **pieces of** **paper**.
An **electronic** **balance** is used to measure **weight** accurately.
It is commonly used in **laboratories** to weigh **chemicals** precisely for experiments.
**Electronic** **balances** are also used to weigh **food**, **groceries**, and **jewelry**.
This device provides **precise** **measurements**, often down to the **milligram** **level**.
**Time** helps us track changes, like day turning into night and the change of seasons.
**Clocks** are commonly used to measure time, but you can also estimate time by **counting** or feeling your **pulse**.
**Electronic** **clocks** and stopwatches measure even **smaller** **durations** of time.
The **SI unit** of time is the **second**.
Units of time include **seconds**, **minutes**, and **hours**.
